summary: This Act is called the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023. It does not apply to Nagaland and tribal areas unless the State Government decides to apply it by official notification.
Defines important terms like 'audio-video electronic means' which includes video calls for evidence or search. Also defines 'bail' as conditional release from custody.
Any mention of laws like IPC or CrPC will now be read as references to Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita and this Act (BNSS), unless specified otherwise.
All offences under the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita will be investigated and tried as per this Sanhita unless stated otherwise.
This Act doesn't affect any special laws or powers given by other laws. Offences under other laws can still be handled under their own procedures.
Lists 4 types of criminal courts: Sessions Judges, Judicial Magistrates (First and Second Class), and Executive Magistrates.
Explains where each court has the authority to conduct trials, based on territory and law.
State Governments can declare cities with over 10 lakh population as 'Metropolitan Areas' for court jurisdiction.
State Governments must set up Sessions Courts for each sessions division. High Courts appoint judges here.
State Government can appoint Assistant Sessions Judges in consultation with the High Court.
